triples.name: Fitness landscape
triples.relevance: The paper quantifies how fitness effects of mutations change across genetic backgrounds and community composition, directly measuring the adaptive landscape.

triples.name: Mutation
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes fitness effects of all possible mutations through genome-wide transposon libraries.

triples.name: Fitness (biology)
triples.relevance: Fitness effects are the central measure used to quantify the adaptive landscape and evolutionary adaptation.

triples.name: Ecosystem diversity
triples.relevance: The paper studies how ecological diversification affects the adaptive landscape in a nascent community.

triples.name: Community (ecology)
triples.relevance: The paper analyzes how community composition affects fitness effects and the adaptive landscape.

triples.name: Escherichia coli
triples.relevance: E. coli is the model organism used in the Long-Term Evolution Experiment from which the strains for this study were derived.

triples.name: E. coli long-term evolution experiment
triples.relevance: The LTEE provides the source population and evolutionary context for the nascent L and S ecotypes studied in this work.

triples.name: Gene knockout
triples.relevance: The paper measures invasion fitness effects of all possible gene knockouts in the coexisting strains.

triples.name: Transposon mutagenesis
triples.relevance: The paper uses genome-wide barcoded transposon libraries to systematically create and measure knockouts.

triples.name: Epistasis
triples.relevance: The paper reveals how epistatic effects (interactions between mutations) combine with ecological effects to shape the adaptive landscape.

triples.name: DNA barcoding
triples.relevance: The paper engineers novel genome-wide barcoded transposon libraries as a method to measure fitness effects across all possible knockouts.
